Nihongi, pp. 109. == Traditional history == According to Nihon Shoki, Nintoku was the fourth son of Emperor Ōjin and the father of three emperors — Richū, Hanzei, and Ingyō . == Events of Nintoku's life == Very little is known about the events of Nintoku's life and reign. Only limited information is available for study prior to the reign of the 29th monarch, Emperor Kimmei.Titsingh, pp. 34-36; Brown, pp. 261-262; Varley, pp. 123-124. Nintoku's reign is marked by Japan's first large-scale engineering projects.Aston, William. (1998). Nihongi, Vol. 1, pp. 254-271. === After his death === This emperor's official name after his death (his posthumous name) was regularized many centuries after the lifetime which was ascribed to Nintoku.Aston (1998), pp. 146-147. According to the Imperial Household Agency, the emperor's final resting place is in an earthen tumulus (kofun) at Sakai.Parry, Richard Lloyd. "Japan guards the emperors' secrets; Ban on digs in ancient imperial tombs frustrates archaeologists," The Independent (London). 12 November 1995; retrieved 2011-10-16.
